title: Material Classification üî¨
ques: Classify materials into **metals, ceramics, polymers, and composites** with examples.

answer.content:
| Class | Bonding | Properties | Examples |
|-------|---------|------------|----------|

title: Crystal Structures üíé
ques: Describe the **BCC, FCC, and HCP** crystal structures.

answer.content:
**Common Metal Crystal Structures:**

| Structure | Atoms/Cell | Packing | Examples |
|-----------|------------|---------|----------|
| **BCC** (Body-Centered Cubic) | 2 | 68% | Fe (Œ±), W, Cr |
| **FCC** (Face-Centered Cubic) | 4 | 74% | Al, Cu, Au, Ni |
| **HCP** (Hexagonal Close-Packed) | 6 | 74% | Mg, Zn, Ti |

**Why It Matters:**
- FCC: More slip systems ‚Üí ductile
- BCC: Fewer slip ‚Üí stronger but less ductile
- Affects mechanical properties, phase changes

explanation: Iron changes from BCC to FCC at 912¬∞C. This is basis for heat treatment of steel.

title: Defects in Materials ‚ö†Ô∏è
ques: What are **point defects, dislocations, and grain boundaries**?

answer.content:
**Point Defects:**
| Type | Description |
|------|------------|
| Vacancy | Missing atom |
| Interstitial | Extra atom in gap |
| Substitutional | Different atom in lattice |

**Line Defects (Dislocations):**
- Edge dislocation: Extra half-plane
- Screw dislocation: Spiral distortion
- Enable plastic deformation

**Planar Defects:**
- Grain boundaries: Between crystals
- Stacking faults, twins

explanation: Dislocations explain why metals are weaker than theoretical strength. Controlling them = controlling properties.

title: Heat Treatment üî•
ques: Explain **annealing, quenching, and tempering** of steel.

answer.content:
**Heat Treatment Processes:**

| Process | Procedure | Result |
|---------|-----------|--------|
| **Annealing** | Heat, slow cool | Soft, ductile, stress-free |
| **Quenching** | Heat, rapid cool (water/oil) | Hard but brittle (martensite) |
| **Tempering** | Reheat quenched steel, cool | Reduced brittleness |
| **Normalizing** | Air cool from austenite | Uniform grain structure |

**Combined:** Quench + Temper = Strong and tough

explanation: Hardenability varies with alloying elements. Jominy test measures it.

title: Mechanical Testing üîß
ques: Describe **tensile testing** and the properties it measures.

answer.content:
**Tensile Test:**
Pull specimen until failure

**From Stress-Strain Curve:**
| Property | Definition |
|----------|------------|
| Elastic modulus (E) | Slope of linear region |
| Yield strength (œÉ_y) | Onset of plastic deformation |
| Ultimate tensile strength | Maximum stress |
| Elongation | % length increase |
| Reduction in area | % area decrease |

**Necking:** Localized deformation before fracture

explanation: Offset yield (0.2%) used when no clear yield point. Hardness tests (Rockwell, Brinell) are quicker.

title: Corrosion üß´
ques: Explain the **electrochemical basis** of corrosion and methods to prevent it.

answer.content:
**Corrosion = Electrochemical Reaction:**
- Anode: Metal oxidizes (loses electrons)
- Cathode: O‚ÇÇ or H‚Å∫ reduced
- Electrolyte: Conducts ions

$Fe ‚Üí Fe^{2+} + 2e^-$ (anode)
$O_2 + 2H_2O + 4e^- ‚Üí 4OH^-$ (cathode)

**Prevention Methods:**
| Method | Example |
|--------|--------|
| Coatings | Paint, plating |
| Cathodic protection | Zinc anodes |
| Alloying | Stainless steel |
| Design | Avoid moisture traps |

explanation: Galvanized steel uses zinc as sacrificial anode. Passivation forms protective oxide layer.

title: Composite Materials üß©
ques: Explain the **rule of mixtures** for composite properties.

answer.content:
**Rule of Mixtures:**
Property of composite from constituent properties

**Parallel Loading (along fibers):**
$$E_c = E_f V_f + E_m V_m$$

**Perpendicular Loading:**
$$\frac{1}{E_c} = \frac{V_f}{E_f} + \frac{V_m}{E_m}$$

Where:
- V_f = fiber volume fraction
- V_m = matrix volume fraction
- E = Young's modulus

explanation: Composites are anisotropic‚Äîproperties depend on direction. Design laminates for specific load paths.

title: Nanomaterials üî¨
ques: What makes **nanomaterials** unique and how are they applied?

answer.content:
**Nanoscale Effects (1-100 nm):**
- Large surface area/volume ratio
- Quantum effects (at very small sizes)
- Modified electronic, optical, mechanical properties

**Applications:**
| Material | Use |
|----------|-----|
| Carbon nanotubes | Strong composites |
| Silver nanoparticles | Antibacterial |
| Quantum dots | Displays, imaging |
| Graphene | Electronics, barriers |
| Nano-TiO‚ÇÇ | Sunscreen, photocatalysis |

explanation: Same material at nanoscale can have different properties than bulk. Challenges: characterization, safety, scale-up.
